docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Contributions are welcome, and they are greatly appreciated! Every little bit helps, and credit will always be given.

You can contribute in many ways:

docs.title: Report Bugs
docs.text:
Report bugs at https://github.com/eljefedelrodeodeljefe/py-helmet/issues.

If you are reporting a bug, please include:

  • Your operating system name and version.
  • Any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.
  • Detailed steps to reproduce the bug.

docs.title: Fix Bugs
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for bugs. Anything tagged with "bug" and "help wanted" is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Implement Features
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for features. Anything tagged with "enhancement" and "help wanted" is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Write Documentation
docs.text: Py Helmet could always use more documentation, whether as part of the official Py Helmet docs, in docstrings, or even on the web in blog posts, articles, and such.

docs.title: Submit Feedback
docs.text:
The best way to send feedback is to file an issue at https://github.com/eljefedelrodeodeljefe/py-helmet/issues.

If you are proposing a feature:

  • Explain in detail how it would work.
  • Keep the scope as narrow as possible, to make it easier to implement.
  • Remember that this is a volunteer-driven project, and that contributions are welcome :)

docs.title: Get Started!
docs.text:
Ready to contribute? Here's how to set up py-helmet for local development.

  1. Fork the py-helmet repo on GitHub.
  2. Clone your fork locally
    $ git clone git@github.com:your_name_here/py-helmet.git
  1. Ensure poetry is installed.
  2. Install dependencies and start your virtualenv:
    $ poetry install -E test -E doc -E dev
    $ poetry shell
  1. Create a branch for local development:
    $ git checkout -b name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

Now you can make your changes locally.

  1. When you're done making changes, check that your changes pass the tests, including testing other Python versions, with tox:
    $ tox
  1. Commit your changes and push your branch to GitHub:
    $ git add .
    $ git commit -m "Your detailed description of your changes."
    $ git push origin name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature
  1. Submit a pull request through the GitHub website.

docs.title: Pull Request Guidelines
docs.text:
Before you submit a pull request, check that it meets these guidelines:

  1. The pull request should include tests.
  2. If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated. Put your new functionality into a function with a docstring, and add the feature to the list in README.md.
  3. The pull request should work for Python 3.6, 3.7, 3.8, 3.9 and for PyPy. Check https://github.com/eljefedelrodeodeljefe/py-helmet/actions and make sure that the tests pass for all supported Python versions.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
$ pytest tests.test_py_helmet

To run a subset of tests.

docs.title: Deploying
docs.text:
A reminder for the maintainers on how to deploy. Make sure all your changes are committed (including an entry in HISTORY.md). Then run:

$ poetry patch # possible: major / minor / patch
$ git push
$ git push --tags

Github Actions will then deploy to PyPI if tests pass.

docs.title: Developing CI
docs.text:
The repo supports developing CI changes locally with act

Run the pusg event:

act

Run a specific job:

act -j publish_dev_build -W .github/workflows/dev.yml
• First release on PyPI.

docs.title: Stable release
docs.text:
To install Py Helmet, run this command in your terminal:

pip install py_helmet

This is the preferred method to install Py Helmet, as it will always install the most recent stable release.

If you don't have pip installed, this Python installation guide can guide you through the process.

docs.title: From source
docs.text:
The source for Py Helmet can be downloaded from the Github repo.

You can either clone the public repository:

git clone git://github.com/eljefedelrodeodeljefe/py-helmet

Or download the tarball:

curl -OJL https://github.com/eljefedelrodeodeljefe/py-helmet/tarball/master

Once you have a copy of the source, you can install it with:

pip install .
